results.title: Kermit's swamp years [DVD]
results.creator_credit: David Gumpel, Ritamarie Peruggi and Jim Henson Company
results.brief_description: Travelling down the road to his traditional home at “the swamp,” Kermit (Steve Whitmire) reflects on the good old days aged 12 with pals Croaker and Goggles as they mucked about in the swamp attempting to prove their braveness and pondering a life beyond theirs. When they actually make it to the end of the world as they know it and the road that leads to civilisation, the adventure of a lifetime begins as a pet-store owner who supplies frogs for a science class in which amphibians will be dissected, kidnaps Goggles. Kermit and Croaker, along with a shaggy dog who has just saved their lives, head into the city in search of their friend. It’s also during this time that Kermit discovers that he wants to be in the movies. Features a range of new Muppet characters that do not appear in “The Muppet show”. Features live and Muppet action. Cast also includes Bill Barretta, Dave Goelz and Joey Mazzarino.

results.title: XXX
results.creator_credit: Rob Cohen, Neil H Neil H. Moritz and Revolution Studios
results.brief_description: Director Rob Cohen’s second outing with action star Vin Diesel (their first collaboration was the very successful The Fast and the furious) is a playful hybrid of the James Bond spy movies and extreme sports action. Diesel stars as adrenaline junky Xander Cage who is coerced by the US government into infiltrating a Russian crime ring based in the Czech republic that is planning, amongst other things, the destruction of the world. XXX makes no secret of its Bond appropriations. Cohen gleefully includes in the mix an evil genius based in an elaborate (and not very conspicuous) mountain lair, a beautiful but dangerous woman (Asia Argento), Russian bad guys (yes they’re still bad, irregardless of the Cold War being over), state of the art gizmos and plenty of explosions. It even alludes to the beginnings of a long standing franchise. Cast includes: Samuel L. Jackson, Marton Csokas.

results.title: In search of Anna
results.creator_credit: Esben Storm, Victorian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission and Storm Productions
results.brief_description: Tony has just been released from Pentridge after serving six years for robbery. He sets out to settle old scores and search for his girlfriend Anna. In the process he hitches a ride north with the enigmatic Sam and a relationship develops between them. The theme of coming to terms with the past is expressed formally through the non-chronological structure which produces a split narrative - the Melbourne scenes and the journey north - which inform each other as the story unfolds. Underlying the journey to awareness is the city/country antinomy - the country has the power to liberate what the city has entrapped. Features the music of AC/DC, Rose Tattoo, Stiletto, The Angels and Steve Wright. Cast includes Richard Moir, Judy Morris, Chris Haywood, Bill Hunter, Ian Nimmo, Maurie Fields.

results.title: Pandemonium
results.creator_credit: Haydn Keenan, Tra La La Films, Smart Street Films and KFM Pandemonium
results.brief_description: Haydn Keenan’s “Pandemonium” is a schlock horror movie that aims to displease by entertaining themes of Neo-Nazism, torture, vampirism, incest, sado-masochism, mental illness, necrophilia and bestiality. In the opening sequence Kales Leadingham has escaped from a lunatic asylum. Arriving at a bus stop be relays his travails (in flashback) to a woman seated there. One day at Bondi Beach, Sydney, a woman ‘Dingo Girl’ arrives in search of answers to her past (cue unremitting shots of Dingo Girl’s large breasts, a la Russ Meyer). Shortly after Dingo Girl and Kale enter a warehouse where a bizarre array of subversive types reside. Inhabitants engage in ritualistic Neo-Nazi ceremonies that result in sado-masochistic sex. Amid other activities, a foetus is placed in a blender, Little Adolph has his penis cut off, cloning experiments go awry - whilst numerous musical interludes interrupt the action. Deliberately provocative, and seeking to shock, this film revels in its low-budget amateurism and artlessness. Aesthetically it shares much in common with “Flesh for Frankenstein” and “Rocky Horror Picture Show” but has no hope of achieving the cult status of these enduring films, principally because its relentlessly over-the-top mood and delivery rob it of any impact as comedy or as horror. The unremitting black humour, shoddy sets, trashy costuming, bad taste themes and poor acting, make “Pandemonium” a curio of Australian filmmaking. Cast includes David Argue, Amanda Dole, Esben Storm, Ian Nimmo, Gary Foley, Haydn Keenan, Ignatius Jones, Lex Marinos.

results.title: Siam sunset
results.creator_credit: John Polson, Al Clark, South Australian Film Corporation, Artist Services, New South Wales Film and Television Office and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: After his wife is killed in a freak accident involving a falling refrigerator, British industrial chemist Perry (Linus Roache) travels to Australia to escape and in search of an elusive paint colour after seeing a photo of the Australian outback in a travel brochure. He joins the budget price Whippet tour bus, a motley crew of travellers that includes an aspiring country and western singer, bickering couples, and a woman (Danielle Cormack) fleeing her violent, drug dealing boyfriend whose money she has stolen. Disaster follows Perry everywhere and Australia is no exception: earth tremors, a deceased roadside trader, inclement weather, a dangerous ex-boyfriend and New Year’s Eve at a roadhouse in the middle of nowhere after their bus crashes. A humorous coach war between the Whippet driver determined to out drive a competing driver of a swish coach also travelling to Darwin provides a highlight of the film, as is the Australian outback. Cast also includes: Ian Bliss, Roy Billing, Alan Brough, Rebecca Hobbs, Esme Melville.

results.title: Feet first
results.creator_credit: Clyde Bruckman and Harold Lloyd Corporation
results.brief_description: In Harold Lloyd’s second ‘talkie’ he plays a hopelessly inept shoe clerk, determined to improve himself. Masquerading as a millionare he stows away on a cruise ship but gets dumped overboard in a mail sack. A highlight of the film is a high risk scene on the building scaffolding of a skyscraper where our hapless hero unexpectedly finds himself. Cast includes Harold Lloyd, Barbara Kent, Robert McWade and Lillian Leighton.

results.title: People on Sunday
results.creator_credit: Edgar G. Ulmer, Robert Siodmak and Filmstudio
results.brief_description: This pioneering low-budget film made at the very end of the silent era, was an avant-garde blend of feature and documentary. Its lyrical recording of the streetlife of everyday Berlin owes something to the cycle of ‘city symphony’ films popular in the mid-Twenties. Onto this documentary background is grafted a simple narrative focusing on the interactions between five young Berliners—all played by non-professional actors—who spend a typical Sunday together in and around Berlin. The film launched the careers of all six principal filmmakers involved, and had a huge influence on subsequent film movements including the French New Wave, Italian Neorealist and British Free Cinema movements. This restored version contains important scenes previously missing and features a new score by Elena Kats-Chernin. Written by Billie Wilder, Curt Sidomak and Robert Sidomak. Photography, Eugen Schufftan and Fred Zinnemann. Based on an original story by Curt Siodmak.

results.title: Stray dog = Nora Inu
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Shojiro Motoki, Toho Kabushiki Kaisha and Shintoho
results.brief_description: A young detective Murakami (Toshiro Mifune) has his police gun pick-pocketed on a packed bus in Tokyo. Fearing dismissal, Murakami trawls Tokyo’s underbelly encountering a slew of criminals, black market gunrunners and sleazy types in his quest to recover his weapon and halt the murders occurring at the hand of the thief. In Kurosawa’s ninth feature, the pace is languorous, reflecting the oppressive heat of Occupied Tokyo, sapping the resistance of the many characters that pepper the narrative, sweating their way through an excessive heatwave, battling poverty whilst living amid slums and atrocious post-war conditions. Kurosawa presents a fine example of a noir detective movie, exhibiting his technical virtuosity in a series of vignettes as Murakami chases thieves through grimy back alleys, and sleazy dancehalls, as his naivete ebbs away. Gloomy, intense and atmospheric, this film, about an obsessive quest, delineates a loss of innocence for a rookie cop in search of truth where poverty and degradation causes desperation and amorality to thrive in an urban setting. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Monsoon wedding [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Mira Nair, Caroline Baron, Paradis Films, Pandora Films, Mirabai Films, Keyfilms and IFC Productions (US)
results.brief_description: A colourful and dynamic celebration of marriage ritual, family and relationships, set amid the affluent Indian middle-class, Mira Nair’s “Monsoon wedding” also examines problematic generational conflicts and the politics of money and power. Aiditi is a modern woman, frustrated by her long-term affair with a married man, who decides to partake in an arranged marriage to Hemant, an Indian engineer living in Houston. As both chaotic families gather in Delhi for the festivities, ancestral dynamics, errant children and an ambivalent bride complicate the efforts of patriarch, Lalit Verma to organise the wedding. The disorientation of the groom, pondering the machinations of the intricate proceedings, reflects the nature of an extended family, spread across the globe that reunites only occasionally. Convenient plot contrivances and some pat conclusions compromise the script’s more complex demands, which touches on such issues of child abuse and adultery. Nevertheless the sheer exuberance of the film, coupled with a gaudy palette, teeming with marigolds (the traditional Indian wedding flower) displays Nair’s affection for and celebration of ceremony despite the evidence that established rituals are collapsing under the strain of modernisation, pre-marital sex and female emancipation. Cast includes: Naseeruddin Shah, Lillete Dubey, Shefali Shetty, Vasundhara Das, Parvin Dabas.

results.title: Dirty deeds
results.creator_credit: David Caesar, Deborah Balderstone, Bryan Brown and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: David Caesar takes an irreverent swipe at the gangster genre with this film set in the milieu of the 60s crime scene in Australia, which owes much to the spirit of more contemporary crime films such as Guy Richie’s “Lock, Stock and two smoking barrels”. It is 1969 and the criminal underbelly of Sydney’s King’s Cross has proven to be a lucrative business for notorious crime boss, Barry Ryan (Bryan Brown). His small-scale local operation is threatened however when the American Mafia catch wind of Barry’s profitable dealings and decide to muscle their way in. The scene is set for a David and Golliath battle between dodgy crooks and dodgier crooks! Caesar’s script is based partly on truth, particularly events surrounding the infiltration of the American mafia into Australian crime. “Dirty Deeds” uses this as a basis however to comment on the subsequent Americanization of Australian culture, while playfully poking fun at the Aussie laissez faire attitude vs American corporate efficiency. Cast also includes: Toni Collette, Sam Neill, John Goodman, Sam Worthington, Kestie Morassi, William McInnes.
